metadata.title: Craft Labor and Mechanization in Nineteenth-Century American Canning

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change in the canning industry
relevance.relevance: The study examines how mechanization in the canning industry led to labor displacement, particularly focusing on the replacement of skilled craft labor with machines.

dependent_variables.displaced: Craft workers, particularly cappers and processors, were displaced by machinery.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Craft workers faced reduced wages and job security due to mechanization.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Wages for cappers decreased from $3.00 to $1.44 per day after mechanization.

key_themes: Mechanization as a response to craft labor power
text_fragments: 'The Boss-Capper helped hasten the day of his own exit through his overbearing thoughtlessness.'
'Why Cap Longer by Old Methods when Cox's Capper Fills the Bill-It Saves Labor-It Saves Solder-It Never Tires-It Never Strikes.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how mechanization in the canning industry was driven by the need to reduce the power of skilled craft workers and increase managerial control over production.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of growth in the canning industry with increasing demand for canned goods.
historical_context.institutional_context: Craft workers had significant bargaining power, leading to the development of machinery to reduce their control.

outcomes.main_findings: Mechanization in the canning industry reduced the power of craft workers and allowed for the employment of lower-wage workers.
outcomes.conclusions: Mechanization was driven by the need to reduce craft labor's control over production and was facilitated by the emergence of a capital-goods industry.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that mechanization led to a decline in craft union power and a shift towards lower-wage labor.
